Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is celebrating her 86th birthday today. #Ginsburg is the second of four female justices to have served on the high court. She was born in #Brooklyn, New York, in 1933 and spent a large part of her career advocating for gender equality and women's rights. She was recently featured in the film 'On the Basis of Sex,' which followed her through her first big case, and was the subject of a documentary, '#RBG' ‚Äî both within the last year. Ginsberg has been fondly labeled "the Notorious RBG" ‚Äî a play on rapper Biggie Smalls' Notorious B.I.G. nickname, which gained traction after a law student launched a Tumblr account with the moniker highlighting Ginsberg's dissent in the landmark #SupremeCourt case Shelby County v. Holder. Despite suffering health issues with a cancerous growth being removed from her left lung in late December, Ginsburg has returned to work on the bench.
.
üì∏: Cliff Owen / @apnews

#OnThisDay in 1870: Hiram R. Revels was sworn in as the first African-American member of the US #Congress. Questions surrounded his eligibility, as the 14th Amendment only granted #citizenship to African-Americans in 1868, meaning Revels did not meet the 9-year citizenship requirement for senators. With the support of #Senate #Republicans, Revels became the first person of color in Congress, replacing the vacant seat that Sen. Jefferson Davis had abandoned when Davis took on his role in the Confederate #presidency during the #CivilWar. Revels had been a #minister and #chaplain for a black regiment during the Civil War. Revels represented #Mississippi for a year before becoming the president of the historically black #Alcorn Agricultural and Mechanical College. #BlackHistoryMonth
.
üì∑: Brady-Handy photograph collection, Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division

After marrying in Washington D.C., Richard and Mildred Loving returned home to Virginia where they were arrested for violating the state‚Äôs anti-miscegenation statute, a statute which ruled interracial marriage illegal.
.
With the help of the American Civil Liberties Union, the Loving‚Äôs brought a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, eventually appealing to the US Supreme Court.
.
On June 12, 1967 the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that banning interracial marriage is unconstitutional, stating, ‚ÄúThe Fourteenth Amendment requires that the freedom of choice to marry not be restricted by invidious racial discrimination. Under our Constitution, the freedom to marry, or not marry, a person of another race resides with the individual and cannot be infringed by the State.‚Äù
.
#thisdayinhistory #civilrights #msnbc
.
üì∏: AP

This Day in History: June 7, 1893, Mohandas K. Gandhi‚Äôs first act of civil disobedience.
.
Born in India and educated in England, Gandhi practiced law in South Africa.  While on a train at the Pietermaritzburg Station, Gandhi, despite his resistance, was forcibly thrown off of the train‚Äôs first class car because he was an Indian man.
.
This is believed to have initiated his motivation to fight racial discrimination. It marked the beginning of his philosophy of ‚ÄúSatyagraha‚Äù, passive political resistance, and ‚ÄúAhimsa‚Äù, the principle of nonviolence toward all living things.
.
‚ÄúYou must be the change you wish to see in the world.‚Äù -Mahatma Gandhi

This Day in History: June 6, 1968, Robert F. Kennedy passed away.
.
Just after midnight on June 5, Kennedy celebrated his California primary win with supporters at the Ambassador Hotel ballroom in Los Angeles, California.  Leaving the party to go to a press room, Kennedy took a shortcut through the hotel kitchen.  While Kennedy stopped to shake a busboy‚Äôs hand, 24 year old Sirhan Sirhan shot Kennedy three times, mortally wounding him. After undergoing surgery to remove a bullet from his brain, Kennedy was pronounced dead at 1:44am on June 6, 1968.

This Day in History: June 6, 1944, D-Day.
.
Allied powers landed on the beaches of Normandy, France in an effort to liberate Nazi controlled European territory.  The largest invasion by air, land, and sea in military history, the mission was separated into five sectors: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno, and Sword.
.
Allied forces at Omaha Beach were faced with extremely heavy German force, resulting in around 2,000 causalities. In total, more than  4,000 Allied troops were killed. D-Day is credited for laying the foundation for the Allied victory on the Western Front.

Today in History: March 20, 1854 the Republican Party was founded.
.
In the 1850‚Äôs the Whig party was divided between members who supported slavery and those who did not. The abolitionists within the Whig party formed a group and began having their own meetings, which came to be known as the Republican Party.
.
March 20, 1854 is generally remembered as the day the Republican Party was founded. Abraham Lincoln would later become the first Republican president on November 6, 1860.
.
Photo credit: Bettmann Archive

The State Department on Thursday determined who will be allowed into the U.S. following the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision earlier this week to uphold large parts of President Trump‚Äôs travel ban against visitors from six predominantly Muslim countries.
.
Visa applicants from Iran, Sudan, Syria, Libya, Somalia and Yemen must prove a relationship with a parent, spouse, child, adult son or daughter, son-in-law, daughter-in-law or sibling already in the U.S. to enter the country, two State Department officials confirmed to @nbcnews.
.
In addition, all existing visas will still be honored, State Department officials confirmed.
.
The latest guidelines will take effect at 8:00 p.m. ET today. Stay with @MSNBC for the latest as the ban goes into action.

The cameraman who filmed Omran Daqneesh's rescue in Aleppo never saw a child like Omran. 
While most children who are rescued from rubble are crying or screaming, Mustafa al-Sarut said Omran was "traumatized from the shock ... With his innocence, how he wiped the blood off with his hand, he was used to all this -- the airstrikes, the blood -- this is his daily life."
Follow our series on Syria's children of war on msnbc.com and nbcnews.com.
#AlepposChildren #Syria #OmranDaqneesh #Aleppo #war

#Repost @nbcnews „Éª„Éª„Éª
"I came to work so I can feed my parents and earn money," #Aleppo‚Äôs Mohamad Jabas said.
.
Jabas, 11, left school in the second grade to work as a mechanic to help support his family.
.
The image of tiny #OmranDaqneesh was a heart-wrenching reminder of the ceaseless civil war in #Syria and the toll it has taken on the country's #children. During the week, NBCNews.com will tell the story of #AlepposChildren through the link in our profile and on this feed.
.

Britain's new leader Theresa May will move into her official residence at 10 Downing Street Wednesday as Prime Minister David Cameron moves out, but one member of his team is staying: Larry the cat. 
The brown and white tabby is deemed to be a government worker and will continue to live at the famous address even after his boss packs his bags, officials said.

The four-legged resident becomes one of the few British political figures to have survived the turmoil of last month's Brexit referendum. 
Larry is the latest in a line of felines tasked with keeping Downing Street free of rodents. He arrived in 2011 from the London's Battersea Dogs and Cats Home for rescued animals. üê±

Donald Trump's favorite topic on Twitter? Himself. 
A little over a year after Trump made his campaign announcement, NBC News analyzed more than 6,000 tweets from Trump, including retweets, to learn about how the presumptive Republican nominee uses the platform. 
Trump's most commonly used word, excluding filter words like "the" or "and," is "I." Following that is "Thank," which Trump uses about half as often. #Trump2016 comes in third. Read more on NBC.com.

Pictured above is the Ilomantis ginsburgae, named after Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. üêúüêõ
Researchers at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History and Case Western Reserve University announced Wednesday that they had found a new approach to identifying praying mantises, using a "female genitalia character system" instead of the male-oriented one that is customary. "The new species from Madagascar was named in honor of Ruth Bader Ginsburg...for her relentless fight for gender equality." This isn't the first time the pioneer for gender equality has been celebrated in unconventional ways. Tattoos, nail art, and Halloween costumes comprise just a few examples of ginsburgabilia. And now we can add an entire praying mantis species. üì∑ by Rick Wherley/Cleveland Museum of Natural History

#msnbc #ruthbaderginsburg  #notoriousrbg #casewesternreserveuniversity #clevelandmuseumofnaturalhistory #prayingmantis #scotus #supremecourt

It seems Donald Trump's climate concerns are limited to his golf courses. üèå
A statement of environmental impact filed by the Trump International Golf Links & Hotel Ireland, owned by the presumptive Republican nominee, cited rising sea levels and extreme weather due to global warming as the reason the company needed to build a seawall, Politico reported.

David Bowie, the rock and roll visionary whose career spanned six decades, died Sunday. He was 69, and had just released his 25th album, "Blackstar" to strong reviews on Friday. 
Bowie was among the primary innovators and showmen of rock and roll. He didn't just push the envelope, he often manufactured the envelope itself. He told us we could be heroes and took us on otherworldly sonic odysseys.

Bowie conceded he couldn't change time, but Bowie, time and again, changed us. ‚ö°Ô∏èüöÄ Pictured above is Bowie in 1974 at a press conference in Amsterdam, Netherlands. Read more and see more pictures from his awe-inspiring career on MSNBC.com. üì∑ by Gijsbert Hanekroot/Redferns

Happy holidays from all of us at MSNBC! 
#Christmas #RockefellerCenter #RockefellerChristmasTree #MSNBC

Christmas is upon us! Here at Rockefeller Plaza, the Rockefeller Christmas Tree has become a national symbol, coupled with a popular televised event which occurs at the lighting of the tree every year, which started in 1951. Though it has become a triumphant affair, with Norway Spruces regularly peaking above 70 feet, it wasn‚Äôt always so. 
Here in 1931, when Rockefeller Center was in construction during the Great Depression, a much simpler, 20 foot tall debut Rockefeller Christmas Tree was erected by a group of workers. There was reason to celebrate: while most of their colleagues were struggling to find income, here they can be seen receiving their due pay. They reportedly decorated the tree with cranberries, paper garlands and a few tin cans. Today‚Äôs tree is topped with a magnificent 25 thousand-Swarovski-crystal-studded star that is rumored to be worth $1.5 million, debuted in 2004.

Photo by AP 
Check out more from MSNBC's at msnbc.com/photography

Fixing the Sky: Mega-droughts will be more common in a California warmed by climate change. To soften the next one, the state has launched an experiment in "cloud seeding," which involves shooting silver iodide into thunderheads in hopes of wringing them of extra moisture. This Week in History: Amateur Night at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, N.Y. has earned a reputation for both launching stars and crushing dreams. But one of the world‚Äôs most famous stages probably wouldn‚Äôt have become such a fixture in American culture if it weren‚Äôt for the singular talents of Ella Fitzgerald. On Nov. 21. 1934, after having her name picked out at random from a hat, she stepped up to sing and blew away the crowd. Fitzgerald was still a teenager at the time when she won Amateur Night, but she would go on to become one of the most celebrated jazz singers and scatters of all time. Her name still evokes waves of appreciation from modern Apollo Amateur Night audiences, because no matter what stars have graced the stage since her ‚Äì everyone from James Brown to Lauryn Hill -- she was the one who many have credited with making it legendary.

Here, American jazz singer Ella Fitzgerald performs in Las Vegas, Nev., in 1958. Photo by Dennis Stock/@magnumphotos

People performing rituals at the start of a Hindu festival on the banks of the Yamuna River, the largest tributary river of the Ganges. The Yamuna River is considered a very sacred place for Hindu devotees but has become extremely polluted as a result of the area's large industrial complex that dumps toxic waste into the water. 
Sanitation has important implications for health and human capital development. Poor sanitation causes intestinal diseases that reduce the absorption of calories and nutrients, and contribute to malnutrition.

#Worldtoiletday is a global initiative that urges participants to lend their voices to the issues affecting the billions worldwide who don't have access to improved sanitation. (Photo by Massimo Berruti/Agence VU for MSNBC) #msnbc #worldtoiletday #yamunariver

Of the 353 counties in the United States deemed by the federal government to be persistently poor ‚Äî meaning the poverty rate has been above 20% for three consecutive decades ‚Äî 85% are in rural areas that included Native American reservations like Standing Rock and its Oglala Sioux counterparts on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. 
Pictured here, an indigenous man shows the arm tattoos that bear his name, Village Center. Little Eagle is a town in Corson County, South Dakota. The population is 319 and 51.4% live below the poverty level.

„Éª„Éª„Éª
The Standing Rock poverty rate is 43.2%, nearly triple the national average of 14.5%. There is little economic activity to speak of and childhood mortality, suicide and dropout rates are among the highest in the nation. Food insecurity is vast. Access to quality healthcare and education is lacking. Far too many go without electricity or running water. These conditions are made worse by political and economic red tape that stymie growth and development. 
What tribes like the Standing Rock do have, is land and water ‚Äî arguably some of the most beautiful to be seen in the American plains. Tribes have been forced to fight a series of losing battles to control and capitalize on the natural resources found on their land. In North Dakota, where an oil boom has bolstered the state economy and driven the unemployment rate down to just 3.1%, the unemployment rate in Standing Rock is 79%. Pictured here, a Lakota woman in the tribes buffalo pasture north of Fort Yates. Fort Yates is a town in Sioux County, North Dakota. The population is 184 and 44.3% live below the poverty level. 
Check out the fourth and final chapter in our on-going feature The Geography of Poverty "No Man's Land: The Last Tribes of the Plains" by @mattblack_blackmatt and reporter/writer Trymaine Lee. 
You can see the latest installment of this in-depth feature with detailed interactive graphics and powerful photography on msnbc.com/photography (link in profile)

Of the 353 counties in the United States deemed by the federal government to be persistently poor ‚Äî meaning the poverty rate has been above 20% for three consecutive decades ‚Äî 85% are in rural areas that included Native American reservations like Standing Rock and its Oglala Sioux counterparts on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. The Standing Rock poverty rate is 43.2%, nearly triple the national average of 14.5%. Today on MSNBC we launch our fourth and final chapter in our on-going feature The Geography of Poverty "No Man's Land: The Last Tribes of the Plains" by @mattblack_blackmatt and reporter/writer Trymaine Lee. "When talking about poverty, the death of the buffalo, the flood and colonization, they‚Äôve essentially been erasing Native dignity. We‚Äôre the ones that suffer. We‚Äôre the ones that live here. We‚Äôre the ones who have to change that.‚Äù For this chapter and the project in its entirety go to msnbc.com/photography (link in profile)

An auto giant's exit brings Flint, Michigan and its people to their knees. #geographyofpoverty

In the 1960s and 1970s, General Motors employed more than 80,000 of Flint, Michigan's residents.

Today, GM employs about 5,000 workers in Flint. The city has never recovered from the loss and now grapples with widespread poverty and crime. It's consistently ranked among the most violent cities in the country. 
Check out our latest chapter of #GeographyOfPoverty at MSNBC.com (link is in the bio) #poverty #America #RustBelt #Flint #GeneralMotors #jobs

Between 2009 and 2013, some 41.5% of Flint‚Äôs residents lived below the poverty line, compared to just 16.8% of the rest of the state. A quarter of its families have an annual income of below $15,000 a year. The city‚Äôs child poverty rate of 66.5% is nearly 10 percentage points higher than Detroit‚Äôs.

Today, the city of Hiroshima will commemorate the 70th anniversary of the moment on Aug. 6, 1945 when a U.S. Air Force B-29 dubbed the Enola Gay flew over the Japanese city and dropped the nuclear bomb code-named ‚ÄúLittle Boy." Three days later, the U.S. dropped an even larger bomb, ‚ÄúFat Man,‚Äù over Nagasaki. At least 100,000 people were killed instantly across both cities; Japan‚Äôs surrender in World War II came within one week.

Here, a mother and child in Hiroshima, four months after the atomic bomb dropped. (Photo by Alfred Eisenstaedt/Time & Life Pictures/@gettyimages)

For the full photo essay, "Hiroshima 70th anniversary: Nuclear bomb 'should never be used again,'" go to msnbc.com/photography.

Remembering the Cuban Revolution: 
Sixty-two years ago on July 26, 1953, Fidel Castro united a rebel force with systematized plans to overthrow Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. Over the course of several years, the guerrilla war pack amassed revolutionary volunteers as it pushed across the island, winning a series of victories over Batista‚Äôs armed forces. 
The 26th of July movement ultimately triumphed, and the rebels set out on a victory march to the island capital of Havana ‚Äî where Fidel Castro finally arrived on Jan. 8, 1959. 
Photo: First days following Castro's arrival in January 1959 in Havana, Cuba. (Photo by Bob Henriques/Magnum)

The sheer number of poor people in this country is striking: fully 45 million meet the official guidelines for poverty. And that doesn‚Äôt include millions more who are among the working poor ‚Äì those who tip-toe just above the government‚Äôs official poverty line, which for a family of four means an annual income of less than $23,850 and for an individual means an annual income of $11,670. Recent reports suggest more than 50% of food stamp recipients are the working poor. 
You can see the project in its entirety at www.msnbc.com/geographyofpoverty (photo by @mattblack_blackmatt )

A sea of Confederate flags held by screaming Ku Klux Klan members fluttered in front of the South Carolina Statehouse Saturday, just as a counter rally featuring African flags on the other side of the Capitol wrapped up. The Loyal White Knights of the Klu Klux Klan, based in North Carolina, vowed to protest the removal of the Confederate flag from the Statehouse last week ‚Äî and made good on that promise.

About 50 members descended on the Capitol steps waving the rebel banners ‚Äî at least one of which included a Nazi symbol ‚Äî and immediately began shouting racial slurs at attendees of an earlier ‚ÄúCountering the Attack on Black Unity Rally.‚Äù Those protesters were moved behind barricades, a distance away from the Statehouse steps, where they yelled back at the pro-Confederate flag group. About 2,000 people were at the Statehouse at the peak of the two rallies, according to the South Carolina Department of Public Safety. 
Photographer @markpetersonpixs was on assignment covering the disturbing events for @msnbcphoto. You can check out the complete photo essay ‚ÄúKKK rally leads to clashes at South Carolina capitol‚Äù on www.msnbc.com/photography

Following Adolf Hitler‚Äôs suicide on April 30th as Soviet troops advanced on Berlin, Germany signed an unconditional military surrender on May 7th, thus ending the European theater after nearly 6 years of war. Following Germany‚Äôs defeat, massive celebrations broke out in London, Paris, New York and other cities across the world. These teenagers are seniors at Eden Prairie High School in Minnesota and were at the Supreme Court today to rally for marriage equality. "This is going be in the history books someday, and we wanted to be part of it," said one student. #SCOTUS #scotusmarriage

Dmitri Chizhevsky stands in front of protesters with a sign that says: "I survived homophobes in Russia, and I will survive you too." Dmitri is an asylum seeker from Russia who moved here in 2014. He says that in Russia, he was shot in the eye by anti-gay activists and lost an eye. Today, he says he's excited to be at the Supreme Court because "In Russia, you can't imagine this." #SCOTUS #scotusmarriage

Shelly Bailes & Ellen Pontac of Davis, CA have been together 41 years and legally married for 6. They've been LGBT rights activists since 1983. They were in the courtroom for part of today's hearing. They say they're "ecstatic" to be here and it was "a dream come true." Says Shelly: the only thing left now is to count the votes in our favor. As far as I'm concerned, it's gonna be five, six, or seven." #scotusmarriage #SCOTUS #marriageequality
Beth Corbin and Brittanie Holder of Americans United for Separation of Church and State say they are hopeful the Court will rule in favor of marriage equality. #SCOTUS #scotusmarriage
Marietta, who asked her last name be withheld, is from Maryland and says she's out here today because she believes marriage is between one man and one woman. #SCOTUS

Fred Smith of Virginia holds a sign he made with historical images of segregation, with the slogan: "Don't be on the wrong side of history again." Smith says his parents fought for civil rights and now he is fighting for LGBT rights.
@kasie interviews the head of Freedom to Marry at SCOTUS. Watch our coverage live right now at msnbc.com/shift

#Repost @msnbcphoto‚Ä®„Éª„Éª„Éª‚Ä®The White House Correspondents dinner, dubbed the capital‚Äôs ‚ÄúNerd Prom‚Äù is a source of love, criticism, anxiety, festivity, and selfies for the denizens of Washington‚Äôs political world. Last's night‚Äôs events proved to be no different. The event raises thousands of dollars for a scholarship program, whose scholars are honored on stage every year. Over the past few years, the topic of food waste has gone mainstream, largely due to the critical implications of emerging research. For Dan Barber, a chef and co-owner Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the problem is not only how we dispose of our food, but also, the way we create it in the first place. Blue Hill at Stone Barns and the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in upstate New York tackle the larger issue of food waste through education and example. For Earth Day check out this farm-to-kitchen approach towards eliminating food waste at Stone Barns.

Here, a member of the Stone Barns staff works in the greenhouse. ‚ÄúOver the past half century, our agricultural system has grown to new levels to feed new populations. However, the speed of growth and development has created many unintended consequences to adapt to such short-term needs. Reintroducing and adapting age-old practices to our farming system has provided lasting value and health,‚Äù says Jack Algiere, the Four-season Farm Director in charge of the growing operations at Stone Barns. For more on the issue of food waste tune in to MSNBC at 10pm EST for the premiere of the film Just Eat It.

This Week in History: On April 1, 1984, Marvin Gaye was killed by his father, Marvin Gay Sr. Gaye first began singing at the age of four in his church. His father, a minister, often accompanied him on the piano. On April 1st Gaye intervened, on behalf of his mother, in a heated argument between she and his father in their Los Angeles home. Gay Sr. then left the room only to return wielding the gun that Gaye had gifted to him the previous Christmas. The singer was sitting on a bed beside his mother when his father shot him first in the heart, and then again in the shoulder at point-blank range. His father later pleaded no contest to a charge of voluntary manslaughter and was sentenced to a six-year period of probation. Pictured above, Marvin Gaye performs at the Royal Albert Hall in London, England, in September 1976.

Photo by David Redfern/ @gettyimages

This Week in History: On March 24, 1989, the Exxon Valdez oil tanker ran aground off the coast of Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound. The disaster, second only to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon spill, killed thousands of marine, land and air animals, and led to a massive disruption of the Prince William Sound's fragile ecosystem. To this day oil remains in the coast's soil.  Seen here in 1989, workers hold up dead wildlife while aiding in the clean-up effort along the Alaskan shore.

Photo by Paul Fusco/@magnumphotos

This Week in History: Rapper Notorious B.I.G, who was 24, was killed on March 9, 1997. Biggie was riding in a car when another vehicle pulled up beside his and opened fire. His murder has never been solved. Biggie‚Äôs death came only weeks before his new album, ironically titled Life After Death, was scheduled to be released. It rose to No. 1 on the U.S. charts and was certified Diamond in 2000, one of the few hip hop albums to receive this certification. Born in Brooklyn as Christopher Wallace, Biggie was killed just months after his former friend and West Coast rap rival Tupac Shakur was gunned down in a similar crime. This lead to the rise of many theories that the shootings were tied to the rap war between East and West Coast artists and their record companies.

Notorious B.I.G. pictured, March 1, 1997 (Shawn Mortensen/Corbis Outline)

#Repost from @msnbcphoto: ‚Ä®Fifty years ago this week on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama, the American civil rights movement came to a violent and powerful climax in a day that would become known as "Bloody Sunday". Hundreds of predominately black protesters of all ages were attacked in broad daylight with tear gas, billy clubs and even whips by the Alabama National Guard and local law enforcement. They were subject to the violence for simply trying to exercise their First Amendment freedom in a march to shine a national spotlight on legal minority voter suppression in the Deep South. After another failed attempt at the march, and a proceeding legal victory allowing them to continue, the marchers completed their 54 mile journey to the steps of the Alabama State capitol setting the stage for the passage of the historic Voting Rights Act that August.

This weekend President Barack Obama, President George W. Bush and a long list of notable figures including John Lewis who was on the bridge 50 years ago will descend on Selma with thousands of other supporters this weekend to commemorate the march.  Continue to follow along on @msnbcphoto as we share historical images this weekend from the events in Selma, Ala., 50 years ago.

Here, a group of civil rights demonstrators led my Martin Luther King, Jr., march from Selma to Montgomery to fight for black suffrage.

Photo by Bruce Davidson/@Magnumphotos

This Week in History: On Feb. 11, 1990, South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela was freed from prison following 27 years behind bars. After leaving Victor Verster Prison, Mandela returned to political activism, and worked to bring an end to South Africa's racist apartheid system. Following apartheid's end 4 years later, Mandela was elected President in South Africa's first multiracial election, a role he served in for five years. Seen here in 1994, Mandela visits his former jail cell on Robben Island, where he was held for 18 years of his captivity.

Photo by Jurgen Schadeberg/@gettyimages

This Week in History: On Feb. 5, 1968, the Vietnam War saw the beginning of the Battle of Khe Sanh, the location of a U.S. Marine garrison. By the end of January, members of the People‚Äôs Army of North Vietnam (PAVN) had carried out an operation of artillery bombardment on the Marine garrison, which was located in northwest South Vietnam. Once the battle began, it lasted for over two months and came to be considered one of the longest and bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War. Pictured here on March 8, 1968, near the end of the battle, Dr. Joseph W. Wolfe tends to a wounded soldier at a make shift hospital near the garrison. 
Photo by John T. Wheeler/AP  #history #vietnam #vietnamwar #khesanh #war #1960s #america #msnbcphoto #marines #soldier #semperfi #JohnTWheeler

Rosa Parks would have turned 102 on Wednesday, Feb. 4. The civil rights icon sparked a movement with her decision on one December day in 1955, when she chose not to give up her seat on a Montgomery, Alabama, bus to a white man. In a time when transportation was segregated by law in the South, the 42-year-old seamstress remained firm and chose to be arrested, rather than give into a system she felt was deeply unjust. 
On the eve of Parks's birthday, the Library of Congress announces its new Rosa Parks Collection, which includes thousands of manuscripts and photographs.

Here, Rosa Parks is seen in her Detroit home on June 22, 1988. Photo by Michael J. Samojeden/AP.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto: ‚Ä®This Week in History: Holocaust survivors and world leaders gathered on Tuesday at the site of the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp in Poland to commemorate its liberation by the Red Army 70 years ago on Jan. 26 1945. Some 1.1 million people, mostly Jews, were killed at Auschwitz, the site of one of the worlds worst atrocities, between 1940 and 1945.

Here, a prisoner identity photo taken by Wilhelm Brasse, a professional Polish photographer and a prisoner in Auschwitz. He was ordered to document the Nazi prisoners in the camp‚Äôs ‚ÄúErkennungsdienst‚Äù photographic identification unit. Brasse was ordered to burn all of the pictures but in an act of heroism, he saved tens of thousands as evidence of the horrors of Auschwitz.

Photo by Wilhelm Brasse/Auschwitz Museum/AP

Demonstrators make their way along Place de la Republique during a mass unity rally following the recent terrorist attacks, Jan. 11, 2015 in Paris, France. An estimated one million people have converged in central Paris for the Unity March joining in solidarity with the 17 victims of this week's terrorist attacks in the country. French President Francois Hollande led the march and was joined by world leaders in a sign of unity. The terrorist atrocities started on Wednesday with the attack on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, killing 12, and ended on Friday with sieges at a printing company in Dammartin en Goele and a Kosher supermarket in Paris with four hostages and three suspects being killed. A fourth suspect, Hayat Boumeddiene, 26, escaped and is wanted in connection with the murder of a policewoman.

Photo by Dan Kitwood/@gettyimages

This Week in History: On Jan. 5, 1920 the New York Yankees major league baseball team announced its purchase of outfield slugger George Herman "Babe" Ruth (pictured here in 1920) from the Boston Red Sox. Despite the fact that Ruth led the Red Sox to three World Series victories, set new league pitching records, and broke existing home run records Red Sox owner Harry Frazee made the decision to sell Ruth to the Yankees in a deal that later became known as the "Curse of the Bambino." Babe Ruth quickly excelled in New York and in his first season as a Yankee went on to smash his own home run record, hitting 54 home runs that year. He went on to hit 59 homers in 1921, dominating the game, breaking various records and increasing Yankee revenues. In 1923 the team was able to leave the Polo Grounds and build Yankee Stadium, which became known as "the house that Ruth built." Since the trade that landed Ruth in New York, the Yankees won 39 AL pennants and 26 World Series titles and the Red Sox went 86 years without a World Series win. In 2004, the Sox finally broke the curse coming from behind to beat the Yankees in the AL Championship and beating the St. Louis Cardinals to win their first Series since 1918.

Photo by Transcendental Graphics/Getty

Check out more from MSNBC's "Throwback Thursday" at msnbc.com/photography

‚Ä®Celebrating the new year could arguably be the best 24-hour party of the year. As clocks in time zones around the world click over to 2015, some revelers are united by fireworks and flashbulbs, while others come together for prayer and thoughtful reflection. Some cultures believe the noise from fireworks scares away evil spirits and ushers in good luck for the new year.

Here, people look at fireworks during a New Year Celebration in Manila on Jan. 1, 2015. The Philippines is mainly Roman Catholic but the celebrations draw on ancient superstitions and Chinese traditions in which the noise from firecrackers is meant to drive away evil spirits and bring good luck in the coming year. (Photo by Noel Celis/@AFPphoto/@Gettyimages)

‚Ä®This Week in History: A Love Supreme by John Coltrane was recorded with his quartet 50 years ago in one session on Dec. 9, 1964. The album was released the following year in February 1965 by Impulse! Records. A Love Supreme's four phases: "Acknowledgement," "Resolution," "Pursuance" and "Psalms" are tied to Coltrane's spirituality and faith in God. Many regarded the album as one of the most recognizable, most successful jazz albums in history and among Coltrane's greatest works.

Here, John Coltrane performs onstage in 1961 in New York City, N.Y. (Photo by Herb Snitzer/Michael Ochs Archives/ @gettyimages )

#Repost @msnbcphoto‚Ä®In spite of growing national awareness about the commercial sexual exploitation of children, broad-reaching resources remain limited. For Lisa, a young Seattle-area woman struggling to leave a life of sex work and addiction, this is literally a life or death issue. At 13, Lisa was ‚Äúturned out‚Äù by a pimp. The man locked her in a closet for days, selling her for sex. After he ‚Äúbroke‚Äù her, he continued to control her by using violence. He was later arrested and sentenced to prison for murder.

Here, Lisa waits in handcuffs while the SeaTac police detectives who followed her until she was picked up by a ‚Äúdate‚Äù question the man. He was uncooperative and went to jail for the night, but she expressed interest in a drop-in center founded by the police officers as an alternative to incarceration. The center functions as a first point of contact for social services and long-term care. It was Lisa‚Äôs first time hearing of it. Police took her there.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto:For more than six decades, New York‚Äôs Ellis Island stood as the primary clearing house for immigrants, marking their gateway to a new life in the United States. More than 12 million immigrants made their way through the complex, but not all were able to reach the other side. Today marks the 60th anniversary of the closing of the island. The dilapidated walls surrounding the 22 buildings of the historic south side facilities are overgrown with vines and grass. For more than 28 years, the 96-mile stretch of solid concrete around West Berlin that cut off the East was just as much of a physical boundary as it was a symbolic division lining the Iron Curtain. The Berlin Wall ‚Äì first erected Aug. 13, 1961 ‚Äì represented the political oppression of the Cold War that splintered a city in half, separated friends and families, and marked where more than 100 people died trying to cross. Today marks the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, when Germans from East and West Berlin rushed to the climb over the barriers and become united once again.  Pictured here, The Brandenburg Gate, West Berlin, Germany, on the morning of Nov. 11, 1989.

Photo by Raymond Depardon/ @magnumphotos

We‚Äôre in the homestretch of mid-term campaigning and candidates are giving one final push to win voters.  Kentucky‚Äôs senator, Rand Paul, gave a stone-faced speech in support of Republican Mitch McConnell, saying the election would be a ‚Äúrepudiation of President Obama‚Äôs agenda.‚Äù Paul praised McConnell for being a ‚Äúleader in protecting the First Amendment.‚Äù He was likely referring to McConnell‚Äôs opposition to limits on corporate spending in campaigns. Paul also said McConnell had kept the party ‚Äúunified and focused,‚Äù a veiled reference to intra-party fighting. No one expected Muhammad Ali to win ‚ÄòThe Rumble in the Jungle‚Äô. In the lead-up to the fight, Ali did his best to psych out Foreman with his familiar put-downs and claims that his finesse in the ring would trump Foreman‚Äôs brute force. It was all part of a strategy devised by Ali, later christened ‚Äúrope-a-dope,‚Äù to induce Foreman to wear himself early through punching. In the eighth round, as Foreman began to look visibly tired, Ali came alive and unleashed a flurry of jabs on the heavily favored reigning champ. To chants of ‚ÄúAli boma ye‚Äù the master knocked out the upstart and, in one of the most shocking upsets in the history of boxing, regained his title.

Pictured here, an aerial view of George Foreman on canvas during count by referee Zach Clayton after round 8 knockout by Muhammad Ali at Stade du 20 Mai in Kinshasa, Zaire on Oct. 30, 1974.

Photo by #NeilLeifer / @sportsillustrated / @gettyimages 
Look back at the 40th anniversary of the historic fight in our photo essay ‚ÄúRumble in the Jungle: Muhammad Ali's most famous fight turns 40‚Äù on www.msnbc.com/photography

#Repost from @msnbcphoto:South Dakota was spared many of the worst ravages of the recession. Its unemployment rate today is just 3.4%, compared to 5.9% nationally. Financial giants, manufacturers, and other industries have taken root in the state, drawn to its low taxes and disdain for regulations. But the state‚Äôs gains haven‚Äôt lifted up all its residents: The state‚Äôs average wages are among the lowest in the country. Poverty has increased as well, and the state‚Äôs Native American community ‚Äî 9% of the total population ‚Äî has especially lagged behind. Pictured here, Jeavene Running Shield looks out from the balcony of the motel where she lives with her family in Rapid City, South Dakota. ‚ÄùIt was supposed to be a month,‚Äù she says. But it‚Äôs now been three years since the six of them moved into this cramped motel room.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto:This Week in History: The German Democratic Republic, more commonly known as East Germany, formally became a state on Oct. 7, 1949. Comprised of territory occupied by Soviet forces following Germany‚Äôs defeat in World War II (excluding parts of Berlin) the GDR was ostensibly a Soviet satellite state. Its economy lagged compared to West Germany (which received aid from the US, UK and France) and the mass emigration of citizens resulted in the building of the Berlin Wall in 1961, which stood until 1989. Germany was reunified shortly after the Wall‚Äôs demolition. Pictured here, East German soldiers in 1959. 
Photo by Rene Burri/@magnumphotos

The southeastern Turkish town of Suruc, in Sanliurfa province, has seen tens of thousands of refugees, the majority of which are women, children and the elderly. They arrive exhausted and depleted after walking miles to safety on rough roads and carrying their belongings.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto:On the heels of Sunday‚Äôs historic climate march in New York City, and as we usher in fall, one poignant and striking project that shows in stark daylight the effects of climate change is ‚ÄúWhen Fall Came Early: The Drought Along the Arkansas River Basin‚Äù by photographer @jesserieser.

This photograph, titled ‚Äú Drought Study No 3. Muskogee, OK.‚Äù, was made in the wake of the acute drought that swept across America‚Äôs midwest and south in the summer of 2012, and shows how that drought altered the landscape of the Arkansas River Basin, ‚Äúthe backdrop to my childhood,‚Äù Rieser told msnbc. The drought caused the leaves to prematurely turn and fall to the ground months before their natural cycle - some as early as July - with the death of the trees they fell from following close behind. While on the road that summer, Rieser noticed that ‚Äúas the summer progressed, so did the severity of the drought, along with the phenomenon we see in these pictures.‚Äù (Photo by @jesserieser)

#drought #climate #climatechange #environment #arkansasriverbasin #muskogee #oklahoma #seasons #tree #foliage #msnbc

#Repost from @msnbcphoto:This Week in History: On Sept. 20, 2011, the controversial "don't ask, don't tell" (DADT) policy was repealed. From 1993 until 2011, the policy prohibited military personnel from from disclosing his or her sexual orientation, while barring openly gay, lesbian, and bisexual persons from military service. Prior to 1993, the United States Military excluded all gay and lesbian persons from military service. Pictured here, photographs of Melvin Dwork, taken in 1943 when he was in the navy, are seen at his home in New York. In 2011, Nearly 70 years after Dwork was expelled from the Navy for being gay, the military changed his discharge from ‚Äúundesirable‚Äù to ‚Äúhonorable,‚Äù marking what was believed to be the first time the Pentagon had taken such a step on behalf of a World War II veteran since the repeal of ‚Äúdon‚Äôt ask, don‚Äôt tell.‚Äù (Photo by Seth Wenig/AP)

#tbt #throwbackthursday #gayrights #military #navy #DADT #dontaskdonttell #discrimination

#Repost from @msnbcphotoThe world is very far from meeting the Millennium Development Goal on sanitation. According to WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme estimates for 2012, over 1 billion people still defecate in the open. Sanitation has crucial implications for health and human capital development. Poor sanitation causes debilitating intestinal diseases that reduce the absorption of calories and nutrients and contribute to malnutrition. These diseases kill babies and stunt the physical and cognitive development of surviving children. Of those who still go in the open, 600 million of them live in India. Because India is such a densely populated country, it has the highest number of people going in the open per square kilometer, 200 people per square kilometer.  To have any hope of meeting global sanitation targets, the world will need to focus on the subcontinent. Unfortunately, the easy solution of building latrines is not going to solve the problem entirely. The Indian government has pledged to eliminate open defecation by Gandhi‚Äôs birthday in 2019. All eyes should be on India and its government now as it formulates its new Clean India Campaign. Will it be able save the lives of hundreds of thousands of babies, and improve the health, cognitive development, and future prospects of countless others? 
Photo by @massimoberruti / Agence VU for MSNBC

For the complete photo essay "Poor Sanitation Perpetuates a Vicious Cycle of Disease" go to www.msnbc.com/photography

#Repost from @msnbcphoto--- Some 65,000 festival-goers flocked to Nevada‚Äôs Black Rock Desert for Burning Man 2014. Promising to leave without a trace after the week-long celebration, attendees at the annual event form a temporary community based on radical self-expression, community & art. They depart a week later, removing their trash and any remnants that reveal their presence in the desert. Here, spectators watch El Pulpo Mecanico art car, designed and built by Duane Flatmo and Jerry Kunkelan. Made primarily out of recycled and used junk found at a scrap yard, including a 1973 Ford 250 4x4. El Pulpo Mecanico is a 25 foot tall octopus that shoots 30 foot propane fueled flames from the animated tentacles. Photo by @balazsgardi for MSNBC

#Repost from @msnbcphoto--- In the last several months, Russia‚Äôs proxy war in eastern Ukraine ‚Äì supporting an allegedly homegrown, pro-Russian separatist movement ‚Äì has evolved from fomenting rebellion to more overt displays of aggression, including sending columns of tanks, heavy weaponry and thousands of troops to support the rebels across the border. Russia has spun or denied these military movements, admitting this week that Russian troops had entered Ukraine, but claiming they were there on leave and supporting the separatists of their own free will.

The lack of an obvious, traditional act of war has effectively muted international outrage, while Russian propaganda and misdirection have confounded the possibility of a coherent media narrative. ‚ÄúThis is a blatant invasion by Putin and Russia,‚Äù Weber says. ‚ÄúFor people to have speculation that Russia might be invading Ukraine is absolutely absurd.‚Äù The photomontages that emerged ‚Äì the result of a collaboration between @donaldweber and @arthurbondar ‚Äì are spectral, even hallucinatory, blending pictures of ordinary Ukrainian life with symbols of protest, state power and oppression.

For the entire photo essay ‚ÄúUkraine, Through the Looking Glass‚Äù go to www.msnbc.com/photography

#Repost from @msnbcphoto --- This Week in History: On August 9th, 1974, Former President Richard Nixon resigned from office following a series of revelations about his administration's involvement in the Watergate scandal. The Nixon Administration's attempted cover-up of its participation in the break-in at the 1972 Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate complex in DC led to the discovery of multiple abuses of power by his administration, including bugging the offices of political opponents and the harassment of various activists groups and political figures. The scandal also led to the conviction and incarceration of dozens of Nixon's top administration officials. To this day, the incident remains the only resignation of a president in United States history. Pictured here, a contact sheet showing the resignation declaration made by President Nixon as televised from the White House forty years ago. Photo by Rene Burri/ @magnumphotos.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto--- This Week in History: On August 1, 1944, Anne Frank wrote her last diary entry. On August 4th, 1944, following a tip from an anonymous informer, the German uniformed police stormed the annex where Anne Frank and her family had been hiding for two years. The family was arrested and sent to concentration camps, where Anne, her sister Margot, and their mother died. Their father, Otto, was the only family member to survive the war, and later published her diary, the last sentence of which reads: "‚Ä¶when everybody starts hovering over me, I get cross, then sad, and finally end up turning my heart inside out, the bad part on the outside and the good part on the inside, and keep trying to find a way to become what I'd like to be and what I could be if ... if only there were no other people in the world.‚Äù Pictured here, family photo of Anne and Margot Frank at the beach, c. 1935, the family went into hiding in 1942. (Photo by @gettyimages)

#Repost from @msnbcphoto--- This Week in History: On July 13, 1977, a series of lightning strikes at a local New York City power plant caused a massive city-wide blackout that lasted for two days. The blackout occurred during a nationwide economic downturn, and the city was facing a severe financial crisis. Looting and vandalism were widespread; in all, 1,616 stores were damaged in looting and rioting. A total of 1,037 fires were responded to, and 3,776 people were arrested in the largest mass arrest in New York City history. LaGuardia and Kennedy airports were closed down, automobile tunnels were closed because of lack of ventilation, and 4,000 people had to be evacuated from the subway system. A congressional study estimated that the cost of damages amounted to a little over $300 million. Pictured here, pedestrians walk across 34th St. in New York City during the outage. (Photo: Daily News Archive/ @gettyimages)

Take a look back at moments in history with MSNBC's "Throwback Thursday." From politics to pop culture, and everything in between, we'll share images that tell the story of our history. For more check out msnbc.com/photography.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto --- This Week in History: One year ago this week, the United States Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), a law that allowed states to refuse to recognize same-sex marriages. Pictured here, the plaintiff Edith Windsor and her spouse, Thea Spyer, sit together in a caf√© in Holland during the 1970s. Edith and Thea were together for forty years, and married in Ontario in 2007. Spyer died in 2009 after a long battle with MS. After the IRS denied Windsor's claim as Spyer's legal spouse, and compelled her to pay over $350,000 in estate taxes, she began pursuing legal action. After a long battle, on June 26, 2013, DOMA was struck down in a landmark decision that continues to be celebrated as a major victory for gay couples. (Photo courtesy of Edith Windsor)

#Repost from @msnbcphoto --Each year tribal police on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation take about 200,000 calls from residents. Approximately 80% of those calls are alcohol-related. There are some 35 officers responsible for patrolling more than 2 million acres, an area larger than the states of Delaware and Rhode Island combined. Their main goal is enforcement of the reservation's ban on alcohol. Photographer Peter van Agtmael went on night patrol with the tribal police for MSNBC. You can check out the full essay ‚ÄúLaw and Disorder on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation‚Äù on www.msnbc.com/photography 
Here, a man was taken into custody after neighbors complained of loud drunken noises coming from the residence. He ended up spending eight hours in the 'Drunk Tank' to sober up.

This Week in History: On May 29th, 1953, Sherpa Tenzing Norgay (R) and mountaineer and beekeeper Edmund P. Hillary of New Zealand (L) became the first pair of climbers to reach the 29,035-foot summit of Mount Everest. Here, they show the kit they wore when conquering the world's highest peak. Norgay remains one of the most famous mountain climbers in history, and went on to receive the George Medal from Queen Elizabeth II for his efforts on the expedition. 
This past April, an avalanche on Everest swept through and killed 16 Sherpas while they were preparing the climbing route for their commercial clients. It was the deadliest day in the mountain's history. In response to this tragedy and others involving deaths and injuries sustained by Sherpas hired by inexperienced climbers, climbers who burdened Sherpas with unreasonable requests, and the lack of government support for Sherpas injured or killed while working, many Sherpa guides have walked off the job and some climbing companies are no longer providing guides and porters for Everest expeditions.

#everest #sherpa #nepal #mountain #expedition #climbing #tenzingnorgay #edmundhillary #summit #mounteverest #ice #snow #altitude #avalanche #worldshighestpeak

#Repost from @msnbcphoto --- Sunday, Ukrainians will head to the polls to elect a new president, a pivotal moment in the wake of the ouster of the country‚Äôs former Russian-backed President Viktor Yanukovych. The election comes at a precarious time for the region. Russia has annexed the Crimean peninsula and appears to be attempting to do the same in other parts of eastern Ukraine, prompting violence between Ukrainian forces and pro-Russian separatists, whom the West believes have the support of Russia. There are tens of thousands of Russian troops along the eastern Ukrainian border; the Kremlin has said several times that Russian President Vladimir Putin has ordered their withdrawal, but so far there has been no indication that they are following through with such a move.

Photographer Alexander Chekmenev revisits the people he photographed this winter during the Euromaidan uprising and asks them to reflect on Sunday's upcoming presidential election, their hopes for Ukraine's future and their feelings about the movement today.

Here an elderly woman in front of the Trade Unions Building (or Budynok Profspilok) on Khreshchatyk Street, its facade faces the Maidan square. The building was burned by special military forces during the uprising. She helped to disassemble the rubble after snipers killed peaceful protesters. She refused to give her name or show her face because she was scarred and it would have been too dangerous for her as the protesters are considered criminals by the state.

#Repost from @msnbcphoto --- In the Konso Region of southern Ethiopia, the struggle for clean, safe water is a daily reality for women and young girls. ‚ÄúBringing the water is not a simple task,‚Äù says Mariam Bakaule, ‚ÄúThis is the essence of women. Water and woman are synonymous here.‚Äù The village of Jarso, like many of the others in the area, overlooks a vast valley stretching towards the Kenyan border. Yet the relative greenery of the region is deceptive. For the 13,000 people in Jarso, lack of rain in recent years has caused crops to fail.  At the center of this struggle to survive are the women and young girls whose responsibility it is to trek up to five hours a day to reach dry river beds, only to wait in long lines for scant resources. 
Here, a woman who recently gave birth to her baby clings to life while being carried on a make shift stretcher by men in her village. The correlation between the risk of maternal mortality for women in the developing world and access to safe water and sanitation is little understood. When water is gathered for drinking or washing, any contaminants or infectious agents can have a direct effect on maternal health. Infections and repeated worm infections from unsafe sanitation lead to other risks such as malnutrition, stunted growth and fatal obstructed labor. And the physical strain from carrying the water is itself dangerous, resulting in a higher risk of spinal injury, uterine prolapse, rheumatism hernia and spontaneous abortion.

Photo by @mustafahabdulaziz 
For the full story and more photos, visit: http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/photography

#Repost from @msnbcphoto--- This Week in History: On May 5, 1961, @NASA astronaut Alan Shepard became the first American in space after piloting the Freedom 7 spacecraft for a 15 minute sub-orbital flight which concluded with a splash landing in the Atlantic Ocean.  Shepard would return to space ten years later, at age 47, to pilot the Apollo 14 lunar mission, earning his distinction as the oldest person to walk on the moon.
